definition: to faint with blurred vision (idiom); dizzy and eyes dimmed
head/hair style/the top/end/beginning or end/a stub/remnant/chief/boss/side/aspect/first/leading/classifier for pigs or livestock/CL:個|个[ge4]
eye/small hole/crux (of a matter)/CL:隻|只[zhi1],雙|双[shuang1]/classifier for big hollow things (wells, stoves, pots etc)
flower/blossom/CL:朵[duo3],支[zhi1],束[shu4],把[ba3],盆[pen2],簇[cu4]/fancy pattern/florid/to spend (money, time)/(coll.) lecherous/lustful

sentences.english: The fall from the tree dazed her.
sentences.chinese: 她從樹上摔下來摔得頭昏眼花。

sentences.english: There is no fire in the grate, and hunger has made him faint.
sentences.chinese: 壁爐裏沒有柴火，飢餓又弄得他頭昏眼花。

sentences.english: The rapidly changing color dizzied the spectators.
sentences.chinese: 顏色的快速變換使觀衆頭昏眼花。

sentences.english: The sudden bright lights in his eyes blinded him.
sentences.chinese: 突然的強烈光射入他的雙眼使他頭昏眼花。

sentences.english: He looked down from a dizzily high bridge.
sentences.chinese: 他從一座令人頭昏眼花的高橋上往下看。

sentences.english: You might suddenly feel like headache lightheaded . You might also feel sick to your stomach.
sentences.chinese: 你可能會突然感到頭昏眼花，或是胃部不適。

sentences.english: You might suddenly feel lightheaded . You might also feel sick to your stomach.
sentences.chinese: 你可能會突然頭昏眼花痛，也可能會感覺胃不舒服。

sentences.english: People might also feel lightheaded and sick to their stomach.
sentences.chinese: 他們也可能會感到頭昏眼花和胃裏不舒服。

sentences.english: You might suddenly feel light headcahe, you lightheaded . You might also feel sick to your stomach.
sentences.chinese: 你會突然感覺到頭昏眼花，或者感覺到反胃。
泰瑞醒了過來，仍然頭昏眼花。

sentences.english: Malcolm says he was sometimes “dizzy” with hunger.
sentences.chinese: 馬爾科姆說他有時候餓得“頭昏眼花”。

sentences.english: She came over all dizzy just now.
They had eaten only a few pieces when the young Master said he felt dizzy.
sentences.chinese: 才吃了一點，吳少爺就說自己頭昏眼花。

sentences.english: She was lightheaded from the rarefied mountain air.
sentences.chinese: 她在稀薄的高山空氣中頭昏眼花。

definition: to feel oppressed/to be depressed/to feel dejected
lit. heart alarmed, body leaping (idiom); fear and trepidation in the face of disaster
to pour oil on the fire (idiom); fig. to aggravate a situation/to enrage people and make matters worse
to be shocked/to be appalled/to be terrified
to take a tonic or nourishing food to build up one's health
